revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox person | image = | name = Olivier Zahm | image_size = 300px | caption = Zahm pictured in 2018 for ''Tecknikart Magazine '' | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1963|09|25}} | birth_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | nationality = [[French people|French]] | residence = [[Paris]], [[France]] and [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | education = Université Panthéon-Sorbonne | occupation = [[Magazine editor]], [[photographer]], [[art critic]], [[writer]], [[fashion journalist]] | known_for = Editor-in-chief and co-founder of Purple Magazine | years_active = 1985–present | children = 2 | website = {{url|purple.fr}} }} '''Olivier Zahm''' (born 25 September 1963) is a French [[Editing|magazine editor,]] [[art critic]], [[art director]], [[curator]], writer, and [[photographer]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/fashion/04ZAHM.html|title=Publisher in the Warhol Mold|last=Morgan|first=Spencer|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/11/interview-olivier-zahm-on-the-purple-25th-anniversary.html|title=A French Fashion Editor on the Difference Between Paris, New York, and L.A.|last=Swanson|first=Carl|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}{{Cite web|url=http://purple.fr|title=purple DIARY|website=Purple|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-23}} He is the co-founder, owner, and current editor-in-chief of the bi-annual [[art]] and [[fashion]] magazine ''[[Purple]].''{{Cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/m-gens-portrait/article/2015/10/09/olivier-zahm-dandy-a-louer_4786361_4497229.html|title=Olivier Zahm, dandy à louer|work=Le Monde.fr|access-date=2018-09-23|language=fr-FR}}[https://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/olivier-zahm] In addition to his innovative print publishing, he is a recognized pioneering cultural influence at the dawn of the electronic era during ''the [[Digital Revolution]]''[[Digital Revolution|.]] His early blogs{{Cite web|url=http://purple.fr/|title=purple DIARY|website=Purple|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-23}} garnered notoriety, and featured highly stylized photographs taken by him, that took his audience on daily tours of his fantasyland populated by the artists, intellectuals, designers, filmmakers, socialites, models and celebrities who regularly appeared in his magazine{{Cite news|url=https://www.interviewmagazine.com/culture/olivier-zahm-purple-diary|title=The Man and the Brand: Olivier Zahm - Interview Magazine|date=2010-03-10|work=Interview Magazine|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/night/|title=purple NIGHT|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_au/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-au}}. His [[Aesthetics|aesthetic]] has been described as anti-fashion, [[counterculture]], and unfettered by the constraints of the mainstream publishing world{{Cite web|url=https://www.semipermanent.com/profiles/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahm {{!}} Semi Permanent|website=Semi Permanent|language=en|access-date=2018-09-23}}. His online activity served as an early electronic precursor to popular social media platforms like Facebook and Instagram. His magazine remains one of the only independent and privately owned publications of its kind{{Cite news|url=http://www.papermag.com/olivier-zahm-le-provocateur-1427384256.html|title=Olivier Zahm: Le Provocateur|date=2014-09-07|work=PAPER|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}. Created in the beginning of the ''1990s'' - it still remains a major reference for other alternative magazines today{{Cite news|url=http://www.bystylingamsterdam.com/2012/03/05/purples-editor-in-chief-olivier-zahm-accuses-muse-magazine-of-shameless-copying/|title=Purple’s Editor-In-Chief Olivier Zahm accuses Muse Magazine of Shameless Copying!|date=2012-03-05|work=by Styling Amsterdam|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2012/02/olivier-zahm-accuses-purple.html|title=Olivier Zahm Accuses Muse Magazine of Copying Purple|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}. == Early life and education == [[File:Olivier Zahm in 1979.jpg|thumb|333x333px|Zahm pictured in [[1979]] in [[Paris]]]] Olivier Zahm was born and raised in [[Paris]], France.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/community/people/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahmis One of the 500 People Shaping the Global Fashion Industry|work=The Business of Fashion|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB}} He was the eldest of three children born to two university professors. His parents, who were both students at the time of his birth, raised Zahm and his other siblings in student quarters that were designed by [[Charlotte Perriand]] and [[Jean Prouvé]], located at [[:fr:Résidence_universitaire_Jean-Zay|Résidence Universitaire Jean-Zay]] in [[Antony, Hauts-de-Seine|Antony]].{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_us/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-us}}  Much of his early childhood was spent in academic settings, particularly- during the volatile period of civil unrest in France that broke out in [[May 1968]]''.''{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_us/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-us}}  The protests reached such a point that political leaders feared civil war or revolution. The unrest began with a series of student occupation protests against [[capitalism]], [[consumerism]], [[American imperialism]], and traditional institutions, values and order. Many of the new and radical ideas surrounding Zahm, immersing his youth in tumultuous generational discord, stayed with him, shaping his views on art, philosophical ideas and lifestyle choices.  He leveraged his profound formative experience using it as a tool to build aspects and themes that remain prevalent in his personal and professional life in adulthood.  He told The [[The New York Times|New York Times]] in 2010 that he, “remembers summers spent vacationing in the South of France with his parents in a community of like minded free spirits”{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/fashion/04ZAHM.html|title=Publisher in the Warhol Mold|last=Morgan|first=Spencer|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}} - who he labeled hippies. It was the ''1970s'', the decade of sex revolution and Zahm's parents were committed to [[free love]]'','' [[Naturism|nudism]] and [[Polyamory|polyamourous]] relationships. "My parents had a lot of lovers, they had a lot of affairs. At the time, my parents were really part of this alternative movement in Paris but quite bourgeois too. It wasn't San Francisco or New York. It was the French way{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_au/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-au}}." Zahm’s love of magazines began when he was a teenager in the Paris suburbs. “We used to steal porn magazines in the bookstores and shops and look at them during school,” he says. “It was fun and secret. This is where my obsession for magazines comes from. Magazines used to reveal and give us access to sex, fashion, music and art. TV never did that, and books are mostly academic. Magazines were a symbol of freedom.” {{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html|title=Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s Most Libidinal Editor|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}} He studied [[Philosophy|philosophy,]] [[history]], [[semiotics]] and [[literature]] at the [[Sorbonne University|Sorbonne]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.parismatch.com/Culture/Livres/Olivier-Zahm-l-anar-chic-purple-Fashion-156808|title=Olivier Zahm, l’anar chic|last=Match|first=Paris|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}. His father, Claude, taught philosophy, and Zahm was on track to do the same, before realizing, at 25, that he preferred life outside “la tour d’ ivoire.” {{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html|title=Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s Most Libidinal Editor|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}} Zahm's youngest sister committed suicide in 1994 at the age of 20. {{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html|title=Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s Most Libidinal Editor|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}} == Career == Before entering the world of fashion, Zahm worked as an art critic with widespread recognition for his work as a curator as well as his participation in over 150 exhibitions featuring international contemporary art. {{Cite web|url=https://magpile.com/purple-prose/2/|title=Purple Prose , #2|website=Magpile|access-date=2018-09-24}}In responding to the superficial glamour of the 1980s, Zahm co-founded Purple Prose magazine{{Cite web|url=https://magpile.com/purple-prose/about/|title=Purple Prose magazine on Magpile|website=magpile.com|access-date=2018-09-23}}. In the introduction of Purple Anthology, Zahm shares why he chose to create Purple Prose:{{Cite news|url=https://www.rizzoliusa.com/book/9780847830206/|title=Purple Anthology: Art Prose Fashion Music Architecture Sex - Rizzoli New York|work=Rizzoli New York|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/fw-2008-issue-10/purple-anthology/|title=Purple Anthology - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-US}}
''"We launched Purple Prose in the early 1990s without any means, and without any experience, because we wanted to make a magazine that was radically different. We wanted to support the artists around us that no one else supported, much less talked about. It would be a form of opposition of our own".'' {{Cite book|title=Purple Anthology|last=Zahm|first=Olivier|last2=Fleiss|first2=Elein|publisher=Rizzoli|year=2008|isbn=978-0-8478-3020-6|location=New York City|pages=introduction}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Purple-Anthology-Prose-Fashion-Architecture/dp/0847830209|title=Purple Anthology: Art Prose Fashion Music Architecture Sex|date=2008-05-27|publisher=Rizzoli|isbn=9780847830206|editor-last=Zahm|editor-first=Olivier|location=New York|language=English|editor-last2=Fleiss|editor-first2=Elein}}
=== Art critic and curator (1985–1994) === During the beginning of the 80’s Zahm started to observe and take an interest in the art world. He liked the notion of “being everywhere and on the move”, following art fairs, meeting artists, educating himself in the universe of contemporary art while immersing himself into its social landscape.  Zahm’s gift of being a charismatic intellectual and having an eye for contemporary art made itself apparent early on. He found himself penning for the three leading art titles at the time [[Artforum|Art Forum]], Art Flash, [[Texte zur Kunst|Texte Zur Kunst]] and [[Art press|Art Presse]] and introduced a then unknown [[Jeff Koons]], [[Martin Kippenberger]], and [[Larry Clark]] to the European art world.   He started traveling to the United States and Japan, realizing he could set up his own operation and work agenda, 24/7. He told [[I-D|I-D magazine]] in 2010: [[File:Jan Van Osst, Sans titre, 1993.jpg|thumb|Jan Van Osst, Sans Titre, 1993 at L'Hiver De L'amour in [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris|Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville Paris]] curated by Zahm]]
"Freedom for me came from the art world because it was a place where I could meet the artists. I wanted to be a social critic. I was more interested in the category of intellectual, involving art and politics and writing sometimes. But I didn't want to be a writer necessarily, I just wanted to be part of an intellectual world." {{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/en_au/article/9kby7d/purple-reign-tbt-to-2010-when-i-d-met-olivier-zahm|title=purple reign: #tbt to 2010, when i-D met olivier zahm|date=2017-05-04|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en-au}} 
In 1989, while working at [[Artforum]],  Elien Fleiss, then a young gallery curator received a phone call from Zahm. She was looking for an art critic to write a manifesto against a journalist from a daily newspaper who she felt was writing insanities about contemporary art in general. Zahm agreed to do it, and that was the beginning of the encounter, which then became a love story. Their romance was short-lived, but their professional relationship was fruitful.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/04/fashion/04ZAHM.html|title=Publisher in the Warhol Mold|last=Morgan|first=Spencer|access-date=2018-09-23|language=en}}  In 1994, they curated “The Winter of Love,”https://www.moma.org/calendar/exhibitions/4589 a hit show for the [[Musée d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris|Museum of Modern Art in Paris]] that they later took to [[MoMA PS1|P.S. 1]] in [[New York City|New York]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.moma.org/calendar/exhibitions/4589|title=The Winter of Love (L'Hiver de l'Amour) {{!}} MoMA|website=www.moma.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-23}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/france/art-press/20170521/282626032622730|title=PressReader.com - Connecting People Through News|website=www.pressreader.com|access-date=2018-09-23}} In May of  2017, Zahm published a book in collaboration with Donation Grau titled,' Une avant-garde sans avant-garde'.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lespressesdureel.com/ouvrage.php?id=3523|title=Olivier Zahm: Une avant-garde sans avant-garde – Les presses du réel (livre)|website=www.lespressesdureel.com|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://i-d.vice.com/fr/article/3kbd8v/sans-dieu-ni-maitres-petite-lecon-davant-gardisme-par-olivier-zahm|title=sans dieu ni maitre, petite leçon d'avant-gardisme par olivier zahm|date=2017-04-25|work=I-d|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr}}The book is a collection of Zahm’s most significant texts written during the last 30 years. It is above all a radical reading of art from the 1990s to the present. The [[anthology]] tries to decipher this chaotic, contradictory, oppressive, and ultra-creative period. The introductions that precede each chapter contextualize the selected texts, and develop the idea that the 1990s invented an avant-garde without an avant-garde, the issues of which are increasing and intensifying.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lespressesdureel.com/ouvrage.php?id=3523|title=Olivier Zahm: Une avant-garde sans avant-garde – Les presses du réel (livre)|website=www.lespressesdureel.com|access-date=2018-09-24}} {{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.fr/Une-avant-garde-sans-Olivier-Zahm/dp/2840665441|title=Une avant-garde sans avant-garde|last=recherche|first=résultats de|last2=Grau|first2=Donatien|date=2017-03-01|publisher=Les Presses du réel|isbn=9782840665441|location=Dijon; Zurich}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.jrp-ringier.com/pages/index.php?id_r=4&id_t=&id_p=18&id_b=2748|title=Olivier Zahm - Une avant-garde sans avant-garde|website=jrp-ringier|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite web|url=https://livre.fnac.com/a10494503/Olivier-Zahm-Une-avant-garde-sans-avant-garde|title=Une avant-garde sans avant-garde Essai sur l'art - broché - Olivier Zahm - Achat Livre {{!}} fnac|website=livre.fnac.com|language=fr-FR|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/diary/olivier-zahms-new-book-une-avant-garde-sans-avant-garde-co-edited-with-donatien-grau-is-available-now-to-pre-order/|title=Olivier Zahm's new book "Une avant-garde sans avant-garde" co-edited with Donatien Grau is available now to pre-order! - purple DIARY|date=2017-02-23|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}} === Purple === ==== Early day's of ''Purple'' (1992–2004) ==== Zahm gravitated towards the idea of working with magazines from the conception of his career in art. In 1992 Zahm and his partner Elien Fleiss printed the first issue of Purple Prose, a Parisian literary art zine.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ravelinmagazine.com/posts/les-chroniques-purple/|title=Les Chroniques Purple - Ravelin Magazine|date=2014-08-13|work=Ravelin Magazine|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ebay.com/itm/PURPLE-PROSE-MAGAZINE-ISSUE-1-1992-OLIVIER-ZAHM-ELEIN-FLEISS-RARE-/121033472335|title=PURPLE PROSE MAGAZINE ISSUE #1 1992 OLIVIER ZAHM, ELEIN FLEISS *RARE* {{!}} eBay|website=eBay|language=en|access-date=2018-09-24}} Their goal was to create a new kind of space for artists to present their work and express their ideas; and to design a network through which people working in different disciplines, could easily access new information and each other and contributing to the early 90s alternative indie culture.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/the-colour-purple-1249204.html|title=The colour purple|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB}} {{Cite news|url=https://www.businessoffashion.com/articles/creative-class/olivier-zahms-cocktail-of-intellect-sex-and-the-seventies|title=Olivier Zahm’s Cocktail of Intellect, Sex and the Seventies|date=2015-05-27|work=The Business of Fashion|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB}} Zahm liked the idea of a color sharing the title with an art magazine. [[Dike Blair]] an American artist suggested the title Purple Prose in reference to the literary term in which a prose text is so extravagent, ornate, or flowery that it breaks the flow and draws excessive attention to itself.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/11/interview-olivier-zahm-on-the-purple-25th-anniversary.html|title=A French Fashion Editor on the Difference Between Paris, New York, and L.A.|last=Swanson|first=Carl|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}  Soon after the birth of Purple Prose, Zahm created spin-off publications like Purple Sexe, Purple Fiction and Purple Fashion. Zahm aimed at fusing together his two worlds, fashion and art, in creating Purple Fashion.{{Cite web|url=https://magpile.com/purple-prose/1/|title=Purple Prose , #1|website=Magpile|access-date=2018-09-24}}  A typical issue featured interviews, articles and presentations covering a wide range of topics and disciplines which include; film and video, politics, fashion, architecture, sexuality, science, photography and music. Each issue was built around a loose theme which serves to create a link between subjects-past examples have been: Indian Summer, Violet Violence, Post-Sex. With its international correspondents and cutting-edge design, Purple Prose had the distinctive feel of a truly global art zine. The texts were written in roughly equal parts French and English, without translations.{{Cite web|url=http://adaweb.walkerart.org/purple/info.html|title=Purple Prose|website=adaweb.walkerart.org|access-date=2018-09-24}} For many years the magazine was associated with a realist esthetic, that of the new photography of the early 1990s- of photographers like [[Juergen Teller]], [[Terry Richardson]], [[Wolfgang Tillmans]], and [[Mario Sorrenti]].  From a visual standpoint, the magazine represented a break from 80s imagery (like [[Richard Avedon]]’s photography for [[Versace]], for example.){{Cite news|url=https://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/05/30/fine-print-the-purple-anthology/?mtrref=www.google.com&gwh=2D16E914473B5E10578FBC9B4FEF8E2C&gwt=pay|title=Fine Print {{!}} 'The Purple Anthology'|last=Hruska|first=Jordan|work=T Magazine|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} From an artistic standpoint, the artists from the early 1990s were raising up against art as a capitalist fetish; they were aligning themselves with the artistic social and political practices of the 1970s-- those of performance, [[video art]], [[Fluxus]], and the conceptual and minimalist [[avant-garde]]. The magazine was an integral part of this burgeoning context, which included the deconstruction of fashion by [[Martin Margiela]]{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/ss-2007-issue-7/retrospective-maison-martin-margiela/|title=Retrospective Maison Martin Margiela - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} and [[Comme des Garçons|Comme des Garçsons]]{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/fw-2012-issue-18/rei-kawakubo/|title=Rei Kawakubo - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}; the return of subtle political art, with that of [[Félix González-Torres|Felix Gonzalez- Torres]], [[Maurizio Cattelan]], and [[Philippe Parreno]], among others; photography of [[Juergen Teller]]; and [[Harmony Korine]] and [[Larry Clark]]’s independent filmmaking.{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/ss-2013-issue-19/harmony-korine/|title=Harmony Korine - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/ss-2013-issue-19/larry-clark/|title=Larry Clark - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} ==== ''Purple Magazine'' (2017–present) ==== For its 25th anniversary issue{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2017/11/interview-olivier-zahm-on-the-purple-25th-anniversary.html|title=A French Fashion Editor on the Difference Between Paris, New York, and L.A.|last=Swanson|first=Carl|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}, Purple celebrated the artists and models who incarnated the spirit of the magazine through their style, attitude, and personality: [[Cindy Sherman]], [[Wolfgang Tillmans]], [[Chloë Sevigny|Chloe Savigny]], [[Richard Prince]], [[Paul McCarthy]], [[Susan Cianciolo]] , [[Maurizio Cattelan|Maurizio Cattelan,]] and more.{{Cite news|url=https://www.standardhotels.com/culture/photos-purple-magazine-top-of-the-standard-september-2017|title=PHOTOS: Purple Magazine's 25th Anniversary Party at Top of The Standard|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/magazine/purple-25yrs-anniversary-issue/purple-25-years-25-covers/|title=Purple 25 Years 25 covers - purple MAGAZINE|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} {{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/purple-magazine-anniversary-ralph-lauren-paris-fashion-week|title=Purple Magazine Celebrates Its 25th Anniversary With Ralph Lauren in Paris|work=Vogue|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}It was the first time the magazine printed multiple covers for one issue. 25 different covers showed  25 Purple icons.{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/diary/purple-25th-anniversary-issue-is-out-now/|title=PURPLE 25TH ANNIVERSARY ISSUE IS OUT NOW! - purple DIARY|date=2017-09-05|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.zadig-et-voltaire.com/eu/fr/zadig-backstage/zadig-backstage-society/zadigtribu-purple-25-zadigetvoltaire/|title=Purple 25th anniversary party with Zadig & Voltaire, New York|website=Zadig&Voltaire|language=fr|access-date=2018-09-24}} It was also the first time purple distributed hard-cover magazines instead of the traditional soft-cover print.{{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/eye/parties/purple-magazine-25th-anniversary-olivier-zahm-chloe-sevigny-grace-hartzel-caroline-vreeland-11006313/|title=Purple Magazine Celebrates 25th Anniversary, Founder’s Birthday|last=Templeton|first=Lily|date=2017-09-26|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} {{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/eye/people/purple-reign-10970276/|title=Purple Reign|last=Foreman|first=Katya|date=2017-09-05|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}He described in the editions Edito:
“It’s been years now that younger generations don’t use magazines to express themselves — at least not the way we did back in 1992. Social media now generally satisfy the need for images, contacts, and creativity. Publishing a magazine has become so expensive… An actual print object like Purple is a luxury item, which is why new alternative magazines don’t last more than a few years, are often bought, or simply disappear. Doing a luxury magazine today is one of the paradoxes of the Instagram era, when such things cost nothing… A magazine is not an ego trip… It’s a collective work by a group of creative people who believe in the artistic value of the print media and share a similar vision. (Thanks to all of them!) Every image, every single text, the choice of paper, the layout, even the choice of typefaces matters. Everything matters… Purple is made to last. Purple is made to capture a moment every season… In this period of global Internet obsession and digital amnesia, I think that means something{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/diary/purple-25th-anniversary-issue-is-out-now/|title=PURPLE 25TH ANNIVERSARY ISSUE IS OUT NOW! - purple DIARY|date=2017-09-05|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}"
In 2017 Purple moved their US based headquarters and offices from [[New York City]] to [[Los Angeles]]. {{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/business-news/media/purples-l-a-times-1202780271/|title=Purple’s L.A. Times|last=Foreman|first=Katya|date=2018-08-30|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://milk.xyz/articles/1955-milk-los-angeles-the-purple-magazine-party/|title=Milk Los Angeles – The Purple Magazine Party {{!}} Milk|last=Jon|date=2013-03-28|work=Milk|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} === Freelance editor === In the year 2000, [[Serge July]], the founder and editor-in-chief of French national newspaper [[Libération]] hired Olivier Zahm to launch Liberation Style{{Cite web|url=http://www.ideanow.online/liberation.html|title=Liberation Style|website=www.ideanow.online|language=en|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.parismatch.com/Culture/Livres/Olivier-Zahm-l-anar-chic-purple-Fashion-156808|title=Olivier Zahm, l’anar chic|last=Match|first=Paris|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}, an occasional Saturday supplement to the main paper. 15 issues were published every season until 2005. *Issue 1: Le Retour Paris *Issue 2: Personnalité Multiple *Issue 3: Plein Soleil *Issue 4: L’empire des Signes *Issue 5: Glamour *Issue 6: Special Creation *Issue 7: L’autre Amérique *Issue 8: La nuit *Issue 9: Femmes *Issue 10: Tokyo *Issue 11: Milan *Issue 12: Les Années Fatales *Issue 13: Best of L’ete 2005 *Issue 14: Special Hommes *Issue 15: Mystere Karl {{Cite web|url=https://www.liberation.fr/auteur/9971-olivier-zahm|title=Olivier ZAHM|website=Libération.fr|language=fr|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=https://strip-project.com/archive/9-magazine/the-sisterhood-photography-anette-aurell-i-d-magazine-december-2001-january-2002/687|title=THE SISTERHOOD {{!}} PHOTOGRAPHY ANETTE AURELL {{!}} i-D MAGAZINE {{!}} DECEMBER 2001/JANUARY 2002|last=annaka|date=2016-05-11|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-gb}} In 2009 [[Chanel]] launched its very first magazine: 31 Rue Cambon. Chanel’s goal was to combine sales and information. [[Karl Lagerfeld]] delegated the artistic direction of the magazine which was not available to the public, but instead only the private cliental of Chanel to Zahm {{Cite web|url=https://www.tendances-de-mode.com/2009/11/17/1549-31-rue-cambon-le-magazine-chanel|title=31 Rue Cambon : le magazine Chanel - Tendances de Mode|website=www.tendances-de-mode.com|language=fr|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://purple.fr/diary/the-new-chanel-magazine-31-rue-cambon-issue-3/|title=THE NEW CHANEL MAGAZINE, 31 RUE CAMBON, issue #3 - purple DIARY|date=2011-02-05|work=Purple|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.elle.com/fashion/news/a5892/olivier-zahm-made-a-corporate-mag-for-chanel-16120/|title=Olivier Zahm Made A 'Corporate Mag' for Chanel|date=2011-02-23|work=ELLE|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}} In 2018 Zahm designed a fanzine for [[Gucci]]’s FW2019 collection presented at [[Le Palace]] in Paris. The magazine was the 14th issue of Le Palace Magazine. {{Cite web|url=https://www.gucci.com/us/en/st/stories/inspirations-and-codes/article/spring-summer-2019-le-palace-magazine-fanzine|title=A new issue of Le Palace’s fanzine celebrating Gucci Spring Summer 2019 show by Alessandro Michele, with Purple’s Olivier Zahm and photos by Martin Parr.|website=www.gucci.com|language=en|access-date=2018-10-29}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/french-press-gucci-releases-new-issue-of-cult-fanzine-le-palace|title=Gucci Caps Off Its Paris Takeover by Releasing a New Issue of the Cult Fanzine, Le Palace|work=Vogue|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}} == Photography == Zahm credited Lagerfeld for reigniting his sentiment for taking photos in 2005.  Zahm told WWD in an interview dedicated to Purple’s 25th Anniversary{{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/eye/people/purple-reign-10970276/|title=Purple Reign|last=Foreman|first=Katya|date=2017-09-05|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}:
“He (Lagerfeld) was buying these little digital cameras at the time, Sony Cyber-shots, a little pocket-size, flat, digital camera. He had a pile of them on his table and said: “Take this, if you’ll use it.” We had this long discussion about photography and I said, “Karl how can you want to be a photographer when you were friends with [[Helmut Newton]] because, me, I have [[Juergen Teller]] in my generation and I haven’t been able to do photography since I’ve known him, because he’s the best.” And he said: “Olivier, shut up. You don’t understand, photography is not about getting the right picture, it’s about documenting your everyday life. Remember [[Andy Warhol|Warhol]], do you think he was a good photographer? He always had a camera on him. Do like Warhol, do like me: Don’t let a day go by without taking a picture.”{{Cite news|url=https://wwd.com/eye/people/purple-reign-10970276/|title=Purple Reign|last=Foreman|first=Katya|date=2017-09-05|work=WWD|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-US}}
In 2009, he began documenting his late-night partying escapades in high-contrast black-and-white photographs which appeared on Purple Diary{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/09/09/fashion-s-naughtiest-photographer-olivier-zahm|title=Fashion’s Naughtiest Photographer, Olivier Zahm|last=Jones|first=Justin|date=2014-09-09|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}, a notorious photo blog that would become the seed for a full Purple website. He has had shows of his photographic work at Half Gallery in New York, Colette in Paris , Leadapron in Los Angeles and The Last Gallery in Tokyo. {{Cite news|url=https://www.refinery29.com/olivier-zahm-s-secrets-of-photographing-women-exhibition-opens-tomorrow-at-leadapron-gallery|title=Purple's Olivier Zahm Launches A Photo Exhibit In L.A.|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://hypebeast.com/2010/3/olivier-zahm-purple-diary-exhibition-colette|title=Olivier Zahm "Purple Diary" Exhibition @ colette|work=HYPEBEAST|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.jsbg.me/2011/05/26/%E2%80%9Cthe-secrets-of-photographing-women%E2%80%9D-lexpo-olivier-zahm/|title=“The Secrets of Photographing Women”, l’expo Olivier Zahm|work=JSBG.me|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.semipermanent.com/profiles/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahm {{!}} Semi Permanent|website=Semi Permanent|language=en|access-date=2018-09-24}} In addition to documenting his personal life on social media platform he continues to shoot many editorials and campaigns for various brands including [[Yves Saint Laurent (brand)|Yves Saint Laurent]], [[Chanel]], [[Giorgio Armani]], [[Uniqlo]],  [[Agent Provocateur (lingerie)|Agent Provocateur]], and magazines including [[Lui]], Vogue Russia, and Kadewe among others. {{Cite web|url=https://www.portraitsofgirls.com/photographer/olivier-zahm/|title=Olivier Zahm Archives — Portraits Of Girls|website=Portraits Of Girls|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-24}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/lifestyle/2017/03/03/30001-20170303ARTFIG00275-olivier-zahm-l-art-du-present.php|title=Olivier Zahm, l'art du présent|date=2017-03-03|work=FIGARO|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.luimagazine.fr/sexy/fille-sexy/hedy-olivier-zham-morena/|title=Hedy vue par… Olivier Zahm|date=2015-09-21|work=LUI|access-date=2018-09-24|language=fr-FR}}{{Cite news|url=https://models.com/people/olivier-zahm|title=Olivier Zahm - Photographer|work=MODELS.com|access-date=2018-09-24}} In 2014, Zahm partnered with [[Rizzoli Bookstore|Rizzoli]] published O.Z. Diary, a cosmopolitan 500-page photo diary exposing the lifestyles of the creative elite through a series of intimate, autobiographical photographs. [[Glenn O'Brien]] contributed various texts for the book.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rizzoliusa.com/book/9780847841387/|title=O.Z.: Olivier Zahm: Diary - Rizzoli New York|work=Rizzoli New York|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}}{{Citation|last=Marc Jacobs|title=O.Z.: Olivier Zahm: Diary|date=2014-10-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2D_pyF4urBo|access-date=2018-09-26}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.onetshirt.eu/blogs/onetlikes/15770249-oz-diary-a-photographic-diary-of-fashion-art-and-sex-by-olivier-zahm|title=OZ Diary. A photographic diary of Fashion, Art and Sex by Olivier Zahm – ONETSHIRT|website=www.onetshirt.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}} == Personal life == Zahm has a son, Balthus, with designer Natacha Ramsay-Levi{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/people/natacha-ramsay-levi-meet-paris-it-girl-has-just-named-creative/|title=Who is Natacha Ramsay-Levi? Meet the Paris It-girl who has just been named creative director at Chloé|last=Leaper|first=Caroline|date=2017-03-10|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/27/fashion/chloe-natacha-ramsay-levi-paris-fashion-week.html|title=The New Chloé Girl|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2010/07/olivier_zahms_girlfriend_dumpe.html|title=Olivier Zahm’s Girlfriend Dumped Him and He Blogged About It|work=The Cut|access-date=2018-09-24|language=en}}, and a daughter, Asia, with writer Anna Dubosc. He currently is in a relationship with creative director and former model Amanda Wall. He splits his time between Los Angeles and Paris.{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecut.com/2013/02/olivier-zahm-fashions-most-libidinal-editor.html|title=Riding Around Paris With Olivier Zahm, Fashion’s [[File:Blake Wise And Foolish Virgins 1826.jpg|thumb|300px|right|''The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins'' (1822) by [[William Blake]], [[Tate]] Gallery.]] [[File:The Parable of the Ten Virgins (section) by Phoebe Traquair, Mansfield Traquair Church, Edinburgh.JPG|thumb|300px|The Parable of the Ten Virgins (section) by [[Phoebe Traquair]], Mansfield Traquair Church, [[Edinburgh]].]] The '''Parable of the Ten Virgins''', also known as the '''Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins''' or the '''Parable of the ten bridesmaids''',[[Jerusalem Bible]]: Matthew 25:1-13 is one of the well known [[parables of Jesus]]. According to the [[Gospel of Matthew]] [[s:Bible (King James)/Matthew#Chapter 25|25:1-13]], the five virgins who are prepared for the bridegroom's arrival are rewarded, while the five who are not prepared are [[disowned]]. The parable has a clear [[Christian eschatology|eschatological]] theme: be prepared for the [[Day of Judgment]].John Barton, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=3surkLVdw3UC&pg=PA878 The Oxford Bible Commentary]'', Oxford University Press, 2001, {{ISBN|0-19-875500-7}}, p. 878. It was one of the most popular parables in the [[Middle Ages]], with enormous influence on [[Gothic art]], [[sculpture]] and the [[Sacred architecture|architecture]] of German and French [[cathedrals]]. ==Narrative according to the [[Gospel of Matthew]]== In the Parable of the Ten Virgins, [[Jesus]] tells a story about a party of virgins, perhaps bridesmaids or torchbearers for a procession, chosen to participate in a [[Jewish wedding|wedding]]. Each of the ten virgins is carrying a lamp or [[torch]] as they await the coming of the [[bridegroom]], which they expect at some time during the night. Five of the virgins are wise and have brought oil for their lamps. Five are foolish and have only brought their lamps. At midnight, all the virgins hear the call to come out to meet the bridegroom. Realising their lamps have gone out, the foolish virgins ask the wise ones for oil, but they refuse, saying that there will certainly not (Greek ''ou mē'')John Nolland, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=9cL_kpdUE-oC&pg=PA1006 The Gospel of Matthew: A commentary on the Greek text]'', Eerdmans, 2005, {{ISBN|0-8028-2389-0}}, pp. 1006–1008. be enough for them to share. While the foolish virgins are away trying to get more oil, the bridegroom arrives. The wise virgins then accompany him to the celebration. The others arrive too late and are excluded. {{quotation|Then the Kingdom of Heaven will be like ten virgins, who took their lamps, and went out to meet the bridegroom. Five of them were foolish, and five were wise. Those who were foolish, when they took their lamps, took no oil with them, but the wise took oil in their vessels with their lamps. Now while the bridegroom delayed, they all slumbered and slept. But at midnight there was a cry, "Behold! The bridegroom is coming! Come out to meet him!" Then all those virgins arose, and trimmed their lamps. The foolish said to the wise, "Give us some of your oil, for our lamps are going out." But the wise answered, saying, "What if there isn't enough for us and you? You go rather to those who sell, and buy for yourselves." While they went away to buy, the bridegroom came, and those who were ready went in with him to the marriage feast, and the door was shut. Afterward the other virgins also came, saying, "Lord, Lord, open to us." But he answered, "Most certainly I tell you, I don't know you." Watch therefore, for you don't know the day nor the hour in which the [[Son of man (Christianity)|Son of Man]] is coming.|Matthew 25:1-13, [[World English Bible]]}} ==Interpretations== The parable is one of a sequence of responses to a question in [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] [[s:Bible (King James)/Matthew#Chapter 24|24:3]]: {{quotation|And as he sat upon the mount of Olives, the disciples came unto him privately, saying, Tell us, when shall these things be? and what shall be the sign of thy coming, and of the end of the world?|Matthew 24:3, [[King James Version]]}} Other parables in this sequence include the [[parable of the budding fig tree]] (Matthew 24:32–35) and the [[parable of the Faithful Servant]] (Matthew 24:42–51). The parable of the Ten Virgins reinforces the call for readiness in the face of the uncertain time of this second "coming."R. T. France, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ttTgacXnLV8C&pg=PA349 The Gospel According to Matthew: An introduction and commentary]'', Eerdmans, 1985, {{ISBN|0-8028-0063-7}}, pp. 349-352. It has been described as a "watching parable."''[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11460a.htm Catholic Encyclopedia: PARABLES]. Like the [[parable of the Lost Coin]], it is a parable about women which immediately follows, and makes the same point as, a preceding parable about men.The [[parable of the Lost Coin]] follows the [[parable of the Lost Sheep]] and this parable follows the [[parable of the Faithful Servant]]. [[File:Francken, Hieronymus the Younger - Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins - c. 1616.jpg|thumb|right|300px|This painting by Hieronymus [[Francken]] the Younger (c. 1616) gives a moralistic interpretation of the parable.]] In this parable, Jesus Christ is the bridegroom, echoing the [[Old Testament]] image of God as the bridegroom in [[Book of Jeremiah|Jeremiah]] [[s:Bible (King James)/Jeremiah#Chapter 2|2:2]] and similar passages. The awaited event is the [[Second Coming of Christ]]. [[R. T. France]] writes that the parable is "a warning addressed specifically to those inside the professing church who are not to assume that their future is unconditionally assured." The parable does not criticise the virgins for sleeping, since both groups do that,[[Ben Witherington III|Ben Witherington]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=xGePuntVBhgC&pg=PA43 Women in the Ministry of Jesus: A study of Jesus' attitudes to women and their roles as reflected in his earthly life]'', Cambridge University Press, 1987, {{ISBN|0-521-34781-5}}, p. 43. but for being unprepared as they brought no oil (it is unclear as to whether the foolish virgins succeed in purchasing any oil that night:John R. Donahue, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=9ArODuoyndAC&pg=PA134 Hearing the Word of God: Reflections on the Sunday Readings: Year A]'', Liturgical Press, 2004, {{ISBN|0-8146-2785-4}}, p. 134: "We never know whether they found it, but when they return, the feast has started and the door is barred." most shops would not have been open[[Craig S. Keener]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8C2Y_HaL5W0C&pg=PA597 The Gospel of Matthew: A Socio-Rhetorical Commentary]'', Eerdmans, 2009, {{ISBN|0-8028-6498-8}}, p. 597.[[J. Dwight Pentecost]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=k_VVxjLkN2UC&pg=PA150 The Parables of Jesus: Lessons in life from the Master Teacher]'', Kregel Publications, 1998, {{ISBN|0-8254-3458-0}}, p. 150.). The parable is not written in praise of virginity, and indeed [[Louis of Granada]], in his ''The Sinner's Guide'' of 1555, writes "No one makes intercession with the Bridegroom for the five foolish virgins who, after despising the pleasures of the flesh and stifling in their hearts the fire of concupiscence, nay, after observing the great counsel of virginity, neglected the precept of humility and became inflated with pride on account of their virginity."[[Louis of Granada]], ''[http://www.ewtn.org/library/SPIRIT/granada1-9.htm The Sinner's Guide]'', 1555. [[Spencer W. Kimball]] gave an [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|LDS]] perspective on the difference between the wise and the foolish virgins, and why they could not share the oil: "This was not selfishness or unkindness. The kind of oil that is needed to illuminate the way and light up the darkness is not shareable. How can one share obedience to the principle of tithing; a mind at peace from righteous living; an accumulation of knowledge? How can one share faith or testimony? How can one share attitudes or chastity.... Each must obtain that kind of oil for himself .... In the parable, oil can be purchased at the market. In our lives the oil of preparedness is accumulated drop by drop in righteous living."[[Spencer W. Kimball]], ''Faith Precedes the Miracle'', p. 255.{{cite web|url=http://www.ldsbc.edu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1235:preparation-a-learning-model-discovery&catid=9:devotionals&Itemid=554|title=LDS Business College Devotional - Preparation: A Learning Model Discovery|last=Henrie|first=Lynda|date=July 14, 2010|publisher=[[LDS Business College]]|accessdate=14 June 2011}} ==Authenticity== While "a considerable number of exegetes in fact suppose that the parable of 'The Wise and Foolish Virgins' ultimately goes back to Jesus,"[[Jan Lambrecht (New Testament scholar)|Jan Lambrecht]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=PXfgMs0FIbgC&pg=PA204 Out of the Treasure: The parables in the Gospel of Matthew]'', Peeters, 1991, {{ISBN|90-6831-161-1}}, p. 204. some Bible commentators, because of its [[Christian eschatology|eschatological]] nature, doubt that Jesus ever told this parable and that, instead, it is a parable created by the very early church. A large majority of fellows on the [[Jesus Seminar]], for example, designated the parable as merely similar to something Jesus might have said or simply inauthentic ("gray" or "black").[[Robert W. Funk|Funk, Robert W.]], Roy W. Hoover, and the Jesus Seminar. ''The Five Gospels.'' Harper:San Francisco, 1993, p. 254 Other scholars believe that this parable has only been lightly edited, and is an excellent example of Jesus' skill in telling parables.[[Klyne Snodgrass]], ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=kFyt0VhErywC&pg=PA505 Stories with Intent: A comprehensive guide to the parables of Jesus]'', Eerdmans, 2008, {{ISBN|0-8028-4241-0}}, p. 505. The parable occurs in all ancient [[New Testament manuscripts]], with only slight variations in some words.United Bible Societies, ''The Greek New Testament'', 1983, p. 24. ==Liturgical use== In the [[Catholic Church]], the parable is the Gospel reading for the 32nd Sunday in [[Ordinary Time]] in Cycle A; in the extraordinary form of the Roman rite (Tridentine Mass), the parable is the Gospel reading for Masses of virgins and virgin martyrs (including, by coincidence, St. [[Cecilia of Rome|Cecily]] on November 22 and St. [[Catherine of Alexandria|Catherine]] on November 25, giving it a certain prominence at the fitting time of the end of the liturgical year). The parable is the Gospel reading for the 27th Sunday after [[Trinity Sunday|Trinity]] in the traditional [[Lutheran]] lectionary. In the [[Revised Common Lectionary]], the parable is read in ''[[Proper (liturgy)|Proper]] 27 (32nd Sunday in Ordinary Time)''. {{cite web |url=https://lectionary.library.vanderbilt.edu/texts.php?id=168 |website=https://lectionary.library.vanderbilt.edu/ |publisher=Vanderbilt University |accessdate=23 November 2018}} In the [[Armenian Orthodox Church]] the parable is the main theme of [[Holy Monday]]. A special Church service enacting the parable of the ten virgins is celebrated on Tuesday evening of the [[Holy Week]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} In the [[Syriac Orthodox Church]], the parable is used to commemorate the Sunday [[vespers]] service of [[Nahire]]. Nahire symbolizes our lives in accordance with the 10 virgins that only through a life of dedication, vigilance, fasting and prayer can we be ready for the Bridegroom himself. ==In the arts== This parable has been a popular subject for painting, sculpture, music, and drama. [[File:Schadow,FW-Die klugen und törichten Jungfrauen-1.JPG|thumb|right|[[Friedrich Wilhelm Schadow]], ''The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins'', 1838–1842 (detail), [[Städel|Städel Museum]], Frankfurt am Main.]] ===Painting=== The parable has been depicted in several paintings, including altarpieces in Northern Europe. A recent example, from 1954, is by [[Tove Jansson]]. In the 19th century, the artists of the [[Nazarene movement]] also took up this theme. ===Sculpture=== Sculptures of the wise and foolish virgins were a common motif in mediaeval ecclesial architecture in Europe, especially for the decoration of doorways, and carved figures representing them appear on many of the mediaeval churches and cathedrals of the [[Gothic architecture|Gothic style]], including: [[File:France Strasbourg Cathedral Wise virgins and Christ.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Three wise virgins appear with [[Christ]] on [[Strasbourg Cathedral]].]] * [[Amiens Cathedral]] * [[Auxerre Cathedral]] * [[Laon Cathedral]] * [[Notre Dame de Paris]] * [[Cathedral of Notre-Dame, Reims]] * [[Strasbourg Cathedral]] * [[Erfurt Cathedral]] * [[Cathedral of Magdeburg|Magdeburg Cathedral]] The virgins are also depicted on cathedrals in Switzerland and other countries; the portal leading into the main church of [[Hovhannavank]] (1216-1221) in Armenia has carved scenes from the Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins. The ubiquity of such sculptures has inspired fictional descriptions, such as the carvings on the doors of Kingsbridge cathedral in [[Ken Follett|Ken Follett's]] novel ''[[World Without End (Follett novel)|World Without End]]'', set in the [[Late Middle Ages]]. ===Music=== Several religious musical compositions have been inspired by the parable. Its message was formed into a [[hymn]], "[[Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme]]", by [[Philipp Nicolai]], which [[Johann Sebastian Bach]] used for his [[Chorale cantata (Bach)|chorale cantata]] [[Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme, BWV 140|''Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme'', BWV 140]]. The parable forms the theme for several hymns, including the 19th century hymn "Behold the Bridegroom Cometh" by [[George Frederick Root]], which begins: [[File:StAnnen DieKlugenJungfrauen.jpg|thumb|The five wise virgins together with a personification of the Church (c. 1400), [[St. Anne's Museum Quarter, Lübeck#St. Anne's museum (Museum for history of art and culture)|St. Anne's museum]], Lübeck]]
Our lamps are trimmed and burning,
Our robes are white and clean;
We’ve tarried for the Bridegroom,
Oh, may we enter in?
[[The Wise Virgins]] is a one-act ballet, written in 1941 by [[William Walton]], based on the music of [[Johann Sebastian Bach]], with choreography by Frederick Ashton. It is based on the biblical Parable of the Ten Virgins. "[[Keep Your Lamp Trimmed and Burning]]" is a [[gospel blues]] song based on the parable. It has been recorded by such artists as [[Blind Willie Johnson]], [[Pearly Brown|Reverend Pearly Brown]], and [[Reverend Gary Davis|Rev. "Blind" Gary Davis]]. Non-religious music has also used the parable as a theme, such as the ballet "The wise and the foolish virgins" by Swedish composer [[Kurt Atterberg]] (1887–1974), written in 1920. A reference is made to the parable in the 2002 [[Johnny Cash]] song "[[The Man Comes Around (song)|The Man Comes Around]]," which draws heavily on the Bible. On the 1974 album by [[Genesis (band)|Genesis]] - ''[[The Lamb Lies Down on Broadway]]'', a reference to the parable is made in the song ''[[The Carpet Crawlers]]'': "and the wise and foolish virgins giggle with their bodies glowing bright." American composer [[Emily Freeman-Brown]] has also composed an [[oratorio]] based on the parable. {{citation needed|date=December 2012}} ===Drama=== From early Christian times, the story of the ten virgins has been told as a [[mystery play]]. [[Methodius of Olympus|St Methodius]] wrote the ''Banquet of the Ten Virgins'',''[http://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0623.htm Banquet of the Ten Virgins]'' a mystery play in Greek. ''[[Sponsus]]'', a mid-11th-century play, was performed in both Latin and Occitan. The German play ''[[Ludus de decem virginibus]]'' was first performed on 4 May 1321. There was also a Dutch play of the late Middle Ages. {{Commons category|Ten virgins}} ==See also== * [[Life of Jesus in the New Testament]] * [[Matthew 25]] * [[Ministry of Jesus]] * [[Lamp under a bushel]] * [[Parable of the great banquet]] * [[Parable of the Wedding Feast]] * [[Parable of the Faithful Servant]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Jesus footer}} {{Parables of Jesus|state=expanded}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} [[Category:Christian iconography]] [[Category:Medieval art]] [[Category:Medieval European sculptures]] [[Category:Parables of Jesus|Ten Virgins, Parable of the]] [[Category:Gospel of Matthew]] [[Category:Women in the New Testament]]

{{Infobox artwork | title=Pastoral Pleasure | image=Le Plaisir pastoral - Watteau - Musée Condé.jpg | artist=Antoine Watteau | year=c.1714-1716 | height_metric=31 | width_metric=44 | medium=oil on canvas | museum=Musée Condé | city=Chantilly }} '''''Pastoral Pleasure''''' (French - ''Le Plaisir pastoral'') is a c.1714-1716 [[fête galante]] painting by [[Jean Antoine Watteau]], now in the [[musée Condé]] in [[Chantilly, Oise|Chantilly]].<ref>{{fr icon}} {{cite web|url=http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/joconde_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_1=REF&VALUE_1=00000076655|title=JOCONDE entry}}</ref> <ref>{{fr icon}} {{cite web|url=http://srv225.hosteur.com/musee/conde02/voir.xsp?id=00101-4064&qid=sdx_q0&n=7&e=|title=Museum catalogue entry}}</ref> Two other Watteau paintings survive with extremely similar compositions - the largest and most finished is ''[[The Shepherds (Watteau)|The Shepherds]]'' ([[Schloss Charlottenburg]]), whilst another seems to be a reworking of the Charlottenburg painting (Wildenstein collection). [[Pierre Rosenberg]] argues that the Chantilly version was an oil sketch for the Charlottenburg work. Three other copies of the Chantilly version appeared in 19th and 20th century auctions, but their locations are now unknown.<ref>{{fr icon}} {{fr icon}} Nicole Garnier-Pelle, ''Chantilly, musée Condé. Peintures du xviiie siècle'', Réunion des musées nationaux, coll. « Inventaire des collections publiques de France » (no 38), 1995, 222 p. (OCLC 300738204), p. 149-151 (notice 111).</ref>
The Chantilly work belonged to [[Pierre-Jean Mariette]], a great Watteau collector - it is mentioned as being in his house from at least 1729, around which time [[Nicolas-Henri Tardieu]] made an engraving after it. On 1 February 1775 it was sold after Mariette's death. According to Edmond Goncourt, it was resold in Paris on 11 May 1789, entering the marquis de Maison's collection, which was acquired in its entirety by the [[Henri d'Orléans (1822-1897)|duc d'Aumale]] in 1868 whilst in exile in the United Kingdom. After moving back to France he hung the work in his [[château de Chantilly]], where it still hangs in the [[musée Condé]].<ref>{{fr icon}} Nicole Garnier-Pelle, ''Chantilly, musée Condé. Peintures du xviiie siècle'', Réunion des musées nationaux, coll. « Inventaire des collections publiques de France » (no 38), 1995, 222 p. (OCLC 300738204), p. 149 (notice 111).</ref>
==Analysis== It shows French aristocrats dressed as shepherds - one couple dances to the right and a young couple court each other on a balcony to the left. The painting also includes real peasants in simpler clothes and with simpler gestures, making it easier to distinguish between them and the aristocrats than in other Watteau paintings such as ''The Shepherds''.<ref>Amy Wyngaard, "Switching Codes: Class, Clothing, and Cultural Change in the Works of Marivaux and Watteau", ''Eighteenth-Century Studies'', The Johns Hopkins University Press, vol. 33, no. 4, Summer 2000, p. 523-541</ref> Several details are directly inspired by [[Peter Paul Rubens]]'s paintings - the musician, the man next to him, the shepherd embracing the woman next to him and the dog in the foreground.<ref>{{fr icon}} Nicole Garnier-Pelle, ''Chantilly, musée Condé. Peintures du xviiie siècle'', Réunion des musées nationaux, coll. « Inventaire des collections publiques de France » (no 38), 1995, 222 p. (OCLC 300738204), p. 151 (notice 111).</ref>
==References== <references />

{{Infobox philosopher | region = [[Western philosophy]] | era = [[Contemporary philosophy]] | name = Paul Virilio | image = | caption = | birth_date = 4 January 1932 | birth_place = [[Paris]], France | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|9|10|1932|1|4|df=yes}} | death_placce = Paris, France | school_tradition = [[Continental philosophy]] | alma_mater = [[University of Paris]] | main_interests = [[Aesthetics]] | influences = [[Karl Marx]],<ref>Mark Lacy, ''Security, Technology and Global Politics: Thinking with Virilio'', Routledge, 2014, p. 13.</ref> [[Guy Debord]]<ref>Dana Arnold, Andrew Ballantyne (eds.), ''Architecture as Experience: Radical Change in Spatial Practice'', Routledge, 2004, ch. 7.</ref> | influenced = | notable_ideas = The "war model" of the modern city, the integral accident, dromology, logistics of perception, war of movement }} '''Paul Virilio''' ({{IPA-fr|viʁiljo|lang}}; 4 January 1932 – 10 September 2018)<ref>[https://www.liberation.fr/debats/2018/09/18/mort-de-paul-virilio-penseur-de-l-acceleration-du-monde_1679527 Mort de Paul Virilio, penseur de l'accélération du monde] {{fr icon}}</ref> was a French [[Culture theory|cultural theorist]], [[Urban planning|urbanist]], and [[aesthetic]] philosopher. He is best known for his writings about [[technology]] as it has developed in relation to speed and power, with diverse references to architecture, the arts, the city and the military.
According to two geographers, Virilio was a "historian of warfare, technology and photography, a philosopher of architecture, military strategy and cinema, and a politically engaged provocative commentator on history, terrorism, mass media and human-machine relations."<ref>[[Tim Luke]] & [[Gearóid Ó Tuathail]] (2000) "Thinking Geopolitical Space: The spatiality of war, speed and vision in the work of Paul Virilio", in ''Thinking Space'', [[Mike Crang]] & [[Nigel Thrift]] editors, Routledge, page 361</ref>
==Biography== Paul Virilio was born in [[Paris]] in 1932 to an Italian communist father and a Catholic [[Bretons|Breton]] mother.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Berthou|first1=Benoît|last2=Chautard|first2=Sophie|last3=Guislain|first3=Gilbert|title=100 hommes qui ont fait la France du XXe siècle|date=2003|publisher=Studyrama|page=193|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=NqCdJX6KuPAC}}</ref> He grew up in the northern coastal French region of Brittany. The Second World War made a big impression on him as the city of [[Nantes]] fell victim to the German [[Blitzkrieg]], became a port for the German navy and was bombarded by British and American planes. The "war was his university". After training at the [[École des métiers d'art]], Virilio specialised in stained-glass artwork, and worked alongside [[Henri Matisse]] in churches in Paris. In 1950, he converted to [[Christianity]]. After being conscripted into the army during the [[Algerian war of independence]], Virilio attended lectures in [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]] by [[Maurice Merleau-Ponty]] at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]].<ref name=school>[http://www.egs.edu/faculty/paul-virilio Paul Virilio]. Faculty page at [[European Graduate School]]. Accessed: March 1, 2016.</ref>
In 1958, Virilio conducted a [[Phenomenology (architecture)|phenomenological]] inquiry into military space and the organization of territory, particularly concerning the [[Atlantic Wall]]—the 15,000 Nazi bunkers built during [[World War II]] along the coastline of France and designed to repel any Allied assault. In 1963 he began collaborating with the architect [[Claude Parent]] and formed the [[Architecture Principe]] group (Among the small group of interns were the architects Francois Seigneur and [[Jean Nouvel]]). After participating in the [[May 1968 protests in France|May 1968 uprising in Paris]], Virilio was nominated Professor by the students at the [[École Spéciale d'Architecture]]. In 1973 he became Director of Studies. In the same year, Virilio became director of the magazine ''[[L'Espace Critique]]''. In 1975 he co-organized the [[Bunker Archéologie]] exhibition at the [[Musée des Arts Décoratifs, Paris|Decorative Arts Museum]] in Paris, a collection of texts and images relating to the Atlantic Wall. Since then he has been widely published, translated and anthologised.
Since 1998, Virilio was teaching intensive seminars at [[European Graduate School]].<ref name=school/> His last projects involved working with homeless groups in Paris and building the first Museum of the Accident.<ref name=school/>
==Theoretical arguments==
===The war model=== {{unsourced section|date=September 2014}} Virilio developed what he called the "war model" of the modern city and of human society in general and is the inventor of the term 'dromology', meaning the logic of speed that is the foundation of technological society. His major works include ''[[War and Cinema]]'', ''Speed and Politics'' and ''The Information Bomb'' in which he argues, among many other things, that military projects and technologies drive history. Like some other cultural theorists, he rejects labels - including 'cultural theorist' - yet he has been linked by others with post-structuralism and postmodernism. Some people describe Virilio's work as being positioned in the realm of the 'hypermodern'. He has repeatedly affirmed his links with [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]], for example, and offers humanist critiques of [[modernist art movements]] such as [[Futurism (art)|Futurism]]. Throughout his books the political and theological themes of [[anarchism]], [[pacifism]] and [[Catholicism]] reappear as central influences to his self-proclaimed 'marginal' approach to the question of technology. His work has been compared to that of [[Marshall McLuhan]], [[Jean Baudrillard]], [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Félix Guattari]], [[Jean-François Lyotard]], [[Jacques Ellul]], and others. Virilio was also an [[urbanist]]. After having been a longtime resident of the city of Paris, he moved to [[La Rochelle]].
Virilio's predictions about 'logistics of perception' - the use of images and information in war - (in ''[[War and Cinema]]'', 1984) were so accurate that during the [[Gulf War]] he was invited to discuss his ideas with French military officers. Virilio argued that it was a 'world war in miniature'.
===The integral accident===
Virilio believed that [[technology]] cannot exist without the potential for accidents. For example, Virilio argued that the invention of the locomotive also contained the invention of [[derailment]].<ref name="shipwreck" /> He saw the Accident as a rather negative growth of [[social positivism]] and [[scientific progress]]. He believed the growth of technology, namely [[television]], separates us directly from the events of real space and real time. In it he suggested we lose wisdom and sight of our immediate horizon and resort to the indirect horizon of our dissimulated environment. From this angle, the Accident can be mentally pictured as a sort of "fractal meteorite" whose impact is prepared in the propitious darkness, a landscape of events concealing future collisions. [[Aristotle]] claimed that "there is no science of the accident", but Virilio disagreed, pointing to the growing credibility of [[simulator]]s designed to escape the accident— which he argued is an industry that is born from the unholy marriage of post-WW2 science and the [[military-industrial complex]]. :The first deterrence, nuclear deterrence, is presently being superseded by the second deterrence: a type of deterrence based on what I call 'the information bomb' associated with the new weaponry of information and communications technologies. Thus, in the very near future, and I stress this important point, it will no longer be war that is the continuation of politics by other means, it will be what I have dubbed 'the integral accident' that is the continuation of politics by other means.<ref name=kosovo>John Armitage (October 18, 2000) [http://www.ctheory.net/text_file.asp?pick=132 The Kosovo War Took Place In Orbital Space: Paul Virilio in Conversation], ''Ctheory''</ref>
===Dromology===
''[[wikt:δρόμος|Dromos]]'' is an Ancient Greek noun for race or racetrack, which Virilio applied the activity of racing (Virilio 1977:47). It is with this meaning in mind that he coined the term 'dromology', which he defined as the "science (or logic) of speed“. Dromology is important when considering the structuring of society in relation to warfare and modern media. He noted that the speed at which something happens may change its essential nature, and that which moves with speed quickly comes to dominate that which is slower. 'Whoever controls the territory possesses it. Possession of territory is not primarily about laws and contracts, but first and foremost a matter of movement and circulation.' <ref name=kosovo/>
===Logistics of perception===
In contemporary warfare, logistics does not just imply the movement of personnel, tanks, fuel and so on, but also the movement of images both to and from the battlefield. Virilio talked a lot about the creation of [[CNN]] and the concept of the newshound. The newshound will capture images which will then be sent to CNN, which may then be broadcast to the public. This movement of images can start a conflict (Virilio uses the example of the events following the broadcasting of the [[Rodney King]] footage).<ref>Paul Virilio (1995) ''The Art of the Motor'', Julie Rose translator, page 20, [[University of Minnesota Press]] {{ISBN|0-8166-2571-9}}</ref> The logistics of perception relates also to the televising of military maneuvers and the images of conflict that are watched not only by people at home, but also by the military personnel involved in the conflict. The 'field of battle' also exists as a 'field of perception'.
===War of movement===
For Virilio, the [[transition from feudalism to capitalism]] was driven not primarily by the politics of wealth and production techniques but by the mechanics of war. Virilio argued that the traditional feudal fortified city disappeared because of the increasing sophistication of weapons and possibilities for warfare. For Virilio, the concept of siege warfare became rather a war of movement. In ''[[Speed and Politics]]'', he argues that 'history progresses at the speed of its weapons systems'.
==Reception== Virilio was one of the many cultural theorists (and other [[postmodernists]]) criticized by physicists [[Alan Sokal]] and [[Jean Bricmont]] in 1997 for what they characterize as misunderstanding and misuse of science and mathematics.<ref name=SoBr>[[Alan Sokal]] and [[Jean Bricmont]] (1998) ''[[Fashionable Nonsense|Fashionable Nonsense: Postmodern Intellectuals' Abuse of Science]]'', first published in French as ''Impostures Intellectuelles'' in 1997</ref><ref>Sokal, Alan (2008) ''[[Beyond the Hoax|Beyond the Hoax: Science, Philosophy and Culture]]''</ref> Virilio's works are the subject of chapter 10 of [[Fashionable Nonsense]]. Their criticism consists of a series of quotes (often long) from Virilio's works, and then explanations of how Vilirio confuses basic physics concepts and abuses scientific terminology, to the point of absurdity. In the authors' words:
:The writings of Paul Virilio revolve principally around the themes of technology, communication, and speed. They contain a plethora of references to physics, particularly the theory of relativity. Though Virilio’s sentences are slightly more meaningful than those of Deleuze-Guattari, what is presented as "science" is a mixture of monumental confusions and wild fantasies. Furthermore, his analogies between physics and social questions are the most arbitrary imaginable, when he does not simply become intoxicated with his own words. We confess our sympathy with many of Virilio’s political and social views; but the cause is not, alas, helped by his pseudo-physics.<ref name=SoBr/>{{rp|169}}
A criticism of a passage often reads something like this: :Here Virilio mixes up [[velocity]] (vitesse) and [[acceleration]], the two basic concepts of [[kinematics]] (the description of motion), which are introduced and carefully distinguished at the beginning of every introductory physics course.[221] Perhaps this confusion isn’t worth stressing; but for a purported specialist in the philosophy of speed, it is nonetheless a bit surprising.<ref name=SoBr/>{{rp|170}}
They end their chapter with a long quote followed by this comment: :This paragraph — which in the French original is a single 193-word sentence, whose "poetry" is unfortunately not fully captured by the translation — is the most perfect example of diarrhea of the pen that we have ever encountered. And as far as we can see, it means precisely nothing.<ref name=SoBr/>{{rp|175}}
A book-length cricism of Virilio’s work to 2004 was written by [[Steve Redhead]].<ref name=SR>[[Steve Redhead]] (2004) ''Paul Virilio: Theorist for an Accelerated Culture'', [[Edinburgh University Press]] {{ISBN|0-7486-1927-5}}</ref> He observed: :His scattergun writing style is not always easy to follow, often provoking disorientation and dislocation at the very least. Insights, personal memories, detailed histories, major theoretical leaps and banalities sit side by side.<ref name=SR/>{{rp|137}} He also notes that Virilio does not pass the grade in [[academic studies]]: :Reading Virilio thoroughly does leave the reader with the feeling of many dislocated, undeveloped ideas swirling around often at the level of great generality. The content is often not particularly logical if viewed from a conventional academic perspective in the human or social sciences.<ref name=SR/>{{rp|138}} However, for Law and Popular Culture, Redhead concedes Virilio as a factor: :Paul Virilio’s writing have long had a major role in the theoretical socio-legal studies subdiscipline of law and popular culture which has operated at the intersection of [[critical legal studies]] and [[cultural studies]] for over two decades.<ref name=SR/>{{rp|149}}
In 2014 an analyst of security, technology and global politics noted: :Virilio is unlikely to be read in the 'mainstream' of academia (although one might find his works on the reading lists of a [[military academy]]).<ref name=Lacy>Mark Lacy (2014) ''Security, Technology and Global Politics, thinking with Virilio'', [[Routledge]] {{ISBN|978-0-415-57604-8}}</ref>{{rp|10}} He credits Virilio with balancing the propaganda of progress against the management of fear at some cost: :Virilio draws on and develops points that are made by many critical thinkers from (predominantly) the twentieth century (most notably [[Walter Benjamin]]), assembling ideas in new contexts, creating a vision of the world through concepts and language that is often unsettling, a (re)description that makes the world feel strange and unfamiliar. Virilio’s often alien-sounding concepts attempt to enable us to see the world anew, to view a world that is presented to us in terms of fear and progress as something alien (and alienating), to give a form to feelings and suspicions that remain vague, unclear, uncertain, out of place.<ref name=Lacy/>{{rp|17}}
==Quotes== : 'War was my university. Everything has proceeded from there.'<ref>James Der Derian. [https://web.archive.org/web/20030504135718/http://www.watsoninstitute.org/infopeace/vy2k/futurewar.cfm Future War. A discussion with Paul Virilio] In: virtually2k. 1995.</ref>
: 'The invention of the ship was also the invention of the shipwreck.'<ref name=shipwreck>There are a least two different instances of this quote: 1) "When you invent the ship, you also invent the shipwreck; when you invent the plane you also invent the plane crash; and when you invent electricity, you invent electrocution...Every technology carries its own negativity, which is invented at the same time as technical progress." (''Politics of the Very Worst'', New York: Semiotext(e), 1999, p. 89); 2) “To invent the sailing ship or the steamer is to invent the shipwreck. To invent the train is to invent the rail accident of derailment. To invent the family automobile is to produce the pile-up on the highway.” (''The Original Accident'', Cambridge: Polity, 2007, p. 10).</ref>
Both the [[speed of light]] and [[globalization]] figure in Virilio's writing. At one point he wrote: : 'The speed of light does not merely transform the world. It becomes the world. Globalization is the speed of light.'<ref name=kosovo/> Virilio is also quoted as saying, :'There is no such thing as globalization, there is only virtualization. What is being effectively globalized by instantaneity is time.'<ref name=SR/>{{rp|149}}

[[File:Sophie the Giraffe with baby.jpg|thumb|upright|Sophie the Giraffe]] '''Sophie the Giraffe''' is a [[teether]] – a toy for [[teething]] infants to chew on – in the form of a {{convert|7|in|mm|adj=mid|-high}} [[Hevea brasiliensis|hevea rubber]] [[giraffe]].<ref name=Slate>{{cite news|last=Levin|first=Josh|title=I'm French, Chew on Me: Sophie the Giraffe, the European teething toy that's sweeping America.|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/number_1/2011/03/im_french_chew_on_me.html|accessdate=7 March 2011|newspaper=[[Slate magazine]]|date=7 March 2011}}</ref>
== History == The toy has been made in France (as ''Sophie la Girafe'') since 1961, first in [[Asnières-sur-Oise]], near [[Paris]], by [[Delacoste]], then from 1991 by [[Vulli]], based in [[Rumilly, Haute-Savoie|Rumilly]] in the [[French Alps]]. Its name refers to its launch on 25 May 1961, the feast day of [[Madeleine Sophie Barat|Saint Madeline Sophie Barat]]. It has achieved national icon status in France, according to ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', with more sold each year (816,000 in 2010) than babies are born (796,000).
Sophie is also popular in the United States, where the toy has been available for decades and even appeared in the movie ''[[Three Men and a Baby]]'' (1987), and where it has become the best-selling baby product offered by [[Amazon.com]].<ref name=Slate /> Launched in [[California]] in the trendy [[Hollywood]] area,<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/features/home/la-hm-sophie3-2009oct03,0,2251259.story ''How Sophie the giraffe became a status teether''] in ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' October 3rd 2009.</ref> it became popular through [[word of mouth]], especially on Amazon.com since 2008. The reasons proposed for this success are that it is marketed as eco-friendly<ref name=Slate/> and a growing consumer mistrust of the security and health standards of products made in China since 2007.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/19/business/worldbusiness/19toys.html?_r=1 ''As More Toys Are Recalled, Trail Ends in China ''], ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 19th 2007.</ref>
In 2009, Sophie was recognized as Product of the Year by the [[American Specialty Toy Retailing Association]].
The November 2011 issue of German consumer magazine ''Öko-Test'' reported that Sophie the Giraffe should not be sold in Germany due to a violation of statutory limit values for [[nitrosatable]] substances. The test found 0.781 mg/kg, while the German ''Bedarfsgegenständeverordnung'' (BedGgstV) consumer food and product standard provides for a limit of 0.1 mg/kg. Vulli initially said that another regulation applies, the EU guidelines for toys, with a limit of 1 mg/kg, and obtained a preliminary injunction of the District Court in Berlin banning publication of ''Öko-Test''{{'}}s report. The story was removed from the magazine's website. This injunction was lifted in January 2012. The ''Chemische und Veterinäruntersuchungsamt Stuttgart'' (CVUA) reproduced ''Öko-Test''{{'}}s claims resulting in the German [[Technischer Überwachungsverein]] (TÜV) safety agency pressing charges against Vulli, and ''Öko-Test'' restored the online report to their web site. Vulli responded by recalling Sophie the Giraffe and similar products from German retailers, and offering to exchange it with one produced on or after March 2012, which Vulli says adhere to the stricter German limit.<ref>"[http://oekotest.de/cgi/index.cgi?artnr=11331;gartnr=90;bernr=07;co= ''Öko-Test''{{'}}s summary of the claims, response, court actions and recall (in German)]",''''Öko-Test'''', June 9, 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017073422/http://oekotest.de/cgi/index.cgi?artnr=11331;gartnr=90;bernr=07;co= |date=October 17, 2012 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
